articles.headline: Trump Storms Out of White House Meeting With Democrats on Shutdown
articles.snippet: President Trump slammed a table, then stormed out of a negotiating session with Democrats, declaring it “a total waste of time” as the shutdown stretches on.
articles.abstract: President Trump slammed a table, then stormed out of a negotiating session with Democrats, declaring it “a total waste of time” as the shutdown stretches on.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump stormed out of a White House meeting with congressional leaders on Wednesday after Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she would not fund a border wall even if he agreed to reopen the government, escalating a confrontation that has shuttered large portions of the government for 19 days and counting.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos, Michael Tackett and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: South Korea Raised Taxes in Bid for Growth. So Far, It’s Not Working.
articles.snippet: In contrast to President Trump, President Moon Jae-in of South Korea has embraced a pro-labor program of higher wages and taxes. The early results have been discouraging.
articles.abstract: In contrast to President Trump, President Moon Jae-in of South Korea has embraced a pro-labor program of higher wages and taxes. The early results have been discouraging.
articles.lead_paragraph: INCHEON, South Korea — As President Trump leads a drive to slash taxes and pare back regulation, one major economy is taking a different approach.

articles.headline: Victims of Abuse by Religious Order Priests Say Their Claims Fall Through the Cracks
articles.snippet: Religious orders include the Jesuits, Franciscans and Augustinians. But when a priest in an order is accused of sexual abuse, the abused say they are treated like second-class victims.
articles.abstract: Religious orders include the Jesuits, Franciscans and Augustinians. But when a priest in an order is accused of sexual abuse, the abused say they are treated like second-class victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Larry Antonsen decided to report a priest who sexually abused him during high school, he believed the Archdiocese of Chicago was the right place to go.

articles.headline: CES 2019: It’s the Year of Virtual Assistants and 5G
articles.snippet: A visual tour of the world’s most important tech conference offers a window into the year’s trends, including next-generation wireless networks and the invasion of A.I.
articles.abstract: A visual tour of the world’s most important tech conference offers a window into the year’s trends, including next-generation wireless networks and the invasion of A.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The show must go on.

articles.headline: Washington’s Strong Economy, Financed by Taxpayers, Takes Hit From Shutdown
articles.snippet: As the country nears the end of its third week of a government shutdown, the nation’s capital has borne the brunt of its consequences.
articles.abstract: As the country nears the end of its third week of a government shutdown, the nation’s capital has borne the brunt of its consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was almost lunchtime at a food court downtown and Yonas A. Seyoum, the manager of the Esprinto Café, marched over to the cash register and printed out the morning’s sales.

articles.headline: Trump’s Emergency Powers Threat Could End Shutdown Crisis, but at What Cost?
articles.snippet: If the president invokes emergency powers to build a wall, it could be a mutually face-saving way to reopen the government, but also a violation of constitutional norms.
articles.abstract: If the president invokes emergency powers to build a wall, it could be a mutually face-saving way to reopen the government, but also a violation of constitutional norms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s repeated threat to declare a national emergency so he can build his border wall without congressional approval has been denounced by Democrats as extreme and an overreach. But it could be the only politically realistic way out of the shutdown crisis in the nation’s capital.

articles.headline: Fiat Chrysler Is Expected to Pay Nearly $650 Million in Emissions Case
articles.snippet: The company will pay compensation to car owners and civil penalties to federal and state agencies to settle lawsuits over its use of illegal software, people briefed on the case said.
articles.abstract: The company will pay compensation to car owners and civil penalties to federal and state agencies to settle lawsuits over its use of illegal software, people briefed on the case said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has agreed to pay nearly $650 million to settle lawsuits over its use of illegal engine-control software on diesel vehicles that produced false results on emissions tests, two people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

articles.headline: The U.S. Spent $8 Billion on Afghanistan’s Air Force. It’s Still Struggling.
articles.snippet: Eleven years after the United States began building an Afghan air force, it remains a frustrating work in progress, even as Taliban gains have increased the need.
articles.abstract: Eleven years after the United States began building an Afghan air force, it remains a frustrating work in progress, even as Taliban gains have increased the need.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGHKHAIL, Afghanistan — The A-29 attack plane was a white speck in the bright skies over eastern Afghanistan as it launched a dummy bomb that exploded just yards from the target, a wrecked truck. “Spot on!” said an American adviser watching the exercise.

articles.headline: Investors Were Spooked About Profits. Now Come the Facts.
articles.snippet: After the worst year for stocks in a decade, investors are eager to hear what executives expect in 2019 as companies report fourth-quarter earnings.
articles.abstract: After the worst year for stocks in a decade, investors are eager to hear what executives expect in 2019 as companies report fourth-quarter earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time to see the numbers.

articles.headline: How Companies Like Apple Sprinkle Secrets in Earnings Reports
articles.snippet: Companies repeat themselves in dull earnings reports. But when they make many changes in the text from year to year, it often signals trouble.
articles.abstract: Companies repeat themselves in dull earnings reports. But when they make many changes in the text from year to year, it often signals trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don’t blame Wall Street analysts, rank-and-file investors and journalists for failing to read corporate earnings reports from beginning to end.

articles.headline: Pompeo Speech Lays Out Vision for Mideast, Taking Shots at Obama
articles.snippet: The secretary of state pledged a tougher approach against Iran and more assertive American leadership, notwithstanding the decision to withdraw from Syria.
articles.abstract: The secretary of state pledged a tougher approach against Iran and more assertive American leadership, notwithstanding the decision to withdraw from Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo laid out his vision for America’s role in the Middle East on Thursday, telling a university audience in Cairo that “the age of self-inflicted American shame is over” and that the United States would pursue a more activist policy, despite President Trump’s decision to pull troops out of Syria.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and David E. Sanger
